article.title: Creaky_voice
article.paragraph: Inlinguistics,creaky voice(sometimes calledlaryngealisation,pulse phonation,vocal fry, orglottal fry) is a special kind ofphonationcite journalTitze, I. R.2008The Human Instrument[[Scientific American]]298194–1011822570110.1038/scientificamerican0108-94cite bookTitze, I. R.1994Principles of Voice ProductionPrentice Hall978-0-13-717893-3in which thearytenoid cartilagesin thelarynxare drawn together; as a result, thevocal foldsare compressed rather tightly, becoming relatively slack and compact. They vibrate irregularly at 20–50 pulses per second, about two octaves below the frequency of normal voicing, and the airflow through theglottisis very slow. However, although creaky voice may occur with very low pitch, as at the end of a longintonation unit, it can occur with any pitch.

A slight degree of laryngealisation, occurring in someKorean languageKoreanconsonants for example, is called "stiff voice". TheDanish languageDanishProsody (linguistics)prosodicfeaturestdis an example of a form of laryngealisation that has aphonemephonemicfunction. Creaky voice has been reported to be prevalent in American English as spoken in thePacific Northwestof theUnited States.cite newshttp://www.seattlepi.com/default/article/A-Northwest-dialect-That-s-Goofy-some-say-1174476.phpA Northwest dialect? That's 'Goofy,' some sayPaulson, T.SeattlePI2005-05-26cite webhttp://www.kuow.washington.edu/program.php?idPacific Northwest Dialect Spoken HereBanse, T.2005-07-22Kuow.orgHowever, it has also been reported that use of creaky voice has been spreading among women across the United States.cite journalYuasa, I. P.Creaky Voice: A New Feminine Voice Quality for Young Urban-Oriented Upwardly Mobile American Women?American Speech2010853315–33710.1215/00031283-2010-018cite journalWolk, L.; Abdelli-Beruhe, N. B.; Slavin, D.Habitual Use of Vocal Fry in Young Adult Female SpeakersJournal of Voice2012263e111–e11610.1016/j.jvoice.2011.04.00721917418http://www.slate.com/articles/podcasts/lexicon_valley/2013/01/lexicon_valley_on_creaky_voice_or_vocal_fry_in_young_american_women.html

Some languages, such asJalapa Mazatec languageJalapa Mazatec, use creaky voice as a linguistically significant marker; that is, the presence or absence of creaky voice can change the meaning of a word.cite bookAshbyM.MaidmentJ. A.Introducing Phonetic ScienceCambridge University Press200598978-0-521-00496-1http://books.google.com/books?id2012-06-30
In theInternational Phonetic Alphabet, creaky voice of aPhone (phonetics)phoneis represented by adiacriticaltildeunichar0330COMBINING TILDE BELOWPhonetic symbols in Unicode 200%, for exampleIPA[d̰].
